summary: James (John Travolta) and Mollie Ubriacco (Kirstie Alley) are expanding the family again, this time with Rocks the mutt (Danny DeVito) and Daphne the poodle (Diane Keaton), a mismatched pair who spend their time trading insults the humans can't hear. Meanwhile, James gets a big break working as a private pilot for cosmetic tycoon Samantha (Lysette Anthony), but his employer is determined to pry him away from his wife, his children and, of course, his dogs.

reviews.content: Loved this movie ever since I was a kid especially around the holidays. So cute for kids but with enough adult humor hidden in to give even the adults a giggle or two.

I loved this movie! My kids thought it was so good too! My daughter is 35 and still thinks it's a good movie! We just showed it to her kids! We loved the first two in the series too! Kirstie Ally and John Travolta have great chemistry!

talking pets with Christie Alley and John Travolta as good as ever! for a fun family watch or a mindless good time... check it out!

First movie, 1 talking baby. Second movie, 2 talking siblings. What do we do for the third film, let's add talking dogs. What? Who thought that was a good idea? Who thought making one of the voices for said dogs Danny DeVito? Bad enough that Roseanne was a voice in the second film, now we get to add Danny DeVito and his vocals to things I can live without in a movie. This movie did not need the talking dogs at all. Would have been a little bit better if the kids continued to talk but not much. This movie also could have been given a different name as it could have been just a romantic comedy featuring Travolta and Alley with the evil, horny female boss trying to take advantage of her sexy pilot. This movie tried too hard to involve the talking animals in circumstances they were not needed in. Fails on many levels. It is not even that funny, just sad. Also, for the third time in three movies, bad decisions by selfish people nearly cost children their lives. You would think they would have learned their lesson by now but apparently insanity runs in the Ubriacco family. Watch only if you are a sadist really, it is painful to watch.
Judge me, because i consider it a fun movie.

Truly, a harrowing trilogy about a dysfunctional family constantly on the brink of divorce, about children in constant physical and emotional harm by their increasingly incompetent parents, who are submitted to the cruel manipulations and exploitations of the ruling classï¿ 1/2"now(!) with extreme animal abuse, to boot.
Aside from the children and animals involved, everyone who took part in this cinematic travesty should be ashamed of themselves.

Sure, why not? But if it's leading up to Christmas and you want a feel good, silly movie to watch this is the one.

Fini Bruce Willis et Roseanne Barr, dans le troisième opus de la famille Ubriacco, ce sont les animaux qui parlent. Si le film est affreusement ringard par moments, John Travolta et Kirstie Alley parviennent tout de même à sauver les meubles de bout en bout, malgré un scénario parfois indigent et une réalisation aux abonnés absents, s'il on excepte les deux ou trois séquences rêvées par Kirstie Alley, de très loin la meilleure partie du film. Danny deVito et Diane Keaton sont plutôt performants en chien et chat. Il reste cependant évident qu'il était temps que la saga se finisse avant de dépasser les limites de la débilité, ce que ce troisième opus évite tout juste.
Loved all of these films growing up and they are still fun to watch. This is a cool and fun XMas film to add to the collection.

You know... this ain't a bad movie. I actually really enjoyed this movie. This is by far the most family-accessible installment of the Look Who's Talking trilogy, and I think, this is the most purely enjoyable. Travolta and Alley maintain the good chemistry of the first two movies and DeVito and Keaton fit right in as the voice talent of the dogs. Although the Santa Claus bit was a bit groan-inducing at times,the rest of the humor is charming and pretty witty.  the direction was pretty basic and I think Amy Heckerling did a much better job. Overall, acting was good, story was alright, direction was basic. This was a very enjoyable entry to the series

I was not so sure about a third round of this franchise but I admit that it was a step up from the less than likable second movie. This time the kids are grown up and can talk and the dogs are doing the talking. It sounds like a bad idea but it worked well enough. The talking dogs were not bad, in fact, they were the best part of the movie. The Christmas spirit helps a little, but I thought the holiday angle should have a stronger impact on the plot than it did. John Travolta and Kristy Alley thankfully dial it back from their earlier performances and are tolerable this time around. Travolta has a new job and his new wealthy young boss is set on luring him into an affair. This part of the story is acceptable but it is highly predictable and sort of detracts from the dogs and their relation to the family. Where it is fails the worst is the cheesiness. It does not have enough heart, Christmas sprit, or laughs to give it a memorable identity, but this has been a problem for the whole series.
Look Who's Talking Now is perhaps the best of the three films as it shows good fortune and reversal and the ultimate of tests and temptations for John's character. 10/10

The final installment of the trilogy, Mikey and new addition julie can speak for themselves so the next thing on the agenda is a pet..... Unfortunately for the Ubriacco family they end up with two dogs. Rocks (devito) is a mongrel picked from a local kennel and Daphne (keaton) a pedigree given to the family as a gift, the unlikely make for some funny moments in the movie. James (travolta) job is going well and he had to work double hard for his new employer, samantha (anthony). However job employment was not her only agenda. Some untimely shifts on xmas eve almost cause James's family to fall apart, up until the instincts of the dogs.

This final installment in the Look Who's Talking trilogy is a combination of Make Room For Daddy and The Lady and the Tramp. In the six years since the original Look Who's Talking, Mikey and Julie are now old enough to speak for themselves, so the producers came up with a new gimmick -- talking dogs. The Ubriacco family adopts two surly dogs, Rocks (the voice of Danny DeVito), a street-smart mongrel, and Daphne (voice of Diane Keaton), a snobbish pure bred poodle. The story kicks in with Christmas rapidly approaching and Molly (Kirstie Alley) out of a job. Because of this, her husband James (John Travolta) must work doubly hard to impress his new boss, Samantha (Lysette Anthony). But Samantha, it seems, has hired James for more than what appears in his job description. Samantha contrives a plan to get James to her cabin in the North Woods on Christmas Eve, where she plans to seduce him. James' family races to rescue him from the snowbound cabin, but when their taxi skids off the snow-covered road, it is left to the primal instincts of Rocks and Daphne to save the day.
Pretty good if you like "talking dogs". Of course it depends on what they have to say...and in this, not all that interesting. My dogs say much more interesting things and their delivery is better!

I can, perhaps, understand what made an executive somewhere believe that we need a movie featuring Bruce Willis as a talking baby. I can *almost* imagine what then prompted them to say we needed a sequel featuring Roseanne Barr as another talking baby.

But I cannot possibly conceive of the meeting where it was decided that the only way to follow that up was with a sequel featuring Danny DeVito and Diane Keaton as talking dogs.

I mean, really? Didn't they see Lady and the Tramp? So not only is that movie *bad* it's not even *original*!!!
